attributes.title: Thailand Survey Experiment on Trade and Conflict

q1.value: Thailand Survey Experiment on Trade and Conflict

q2.value: Celeste Beesley | Darren Hawkins | Joel Selway | Elden Griggs

q5.value: We thank the College of Family, Home and Social Sciences at Brigham Young University for funding this study and our colleagues for their comments on the project.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Liberal peace theory suggests that trade reduces conflict between trade partners by increasing the opportunity costs of war. If true, publics should understand this logic and utilize it to oppose conflict when trade is beneficial. On the other hand, populist politicians and others use trade to frighten citizens by focusing on its costs and to promote nationalist messages and the importance of the country’s international status. If publics are responsive to these messages, they are much less likely to identify benefits from trade or to think that trade is an impediment to conflict. They may even think of trade as a reason to engage in higher levels of conflict if they perceive their own country to be hurt by that trade or if trade talk activates feelings of nationalism.

q16.value: We test the effects four different primes about the consequences of trade: absolute gains, absolute losses, relative gains and relative losses. We test the effects on Thais’ attitudes about conflict with Cambodia and Myanmar, two important trade partners with whom Thailand has conflicts. Liberal peace theorists would not think about trade as creating absolute losses but would expect the other three to increase citizen desire for trade and thus reduce citizens’ desire to engage in conflict with a trade partner. We posit instead that all trade primes are likely to activate nationalist and international status concerns and that the losses primes will especially be associated with more hawkish attitudes in response to international conflicts. Details may be found in the pre-analysis plan.

q17.value: We will utilize difference of means tests and regression analyses as laid out in the pre-analysis plan.

They may even think of trade as a reason to engage in higher levels of conflict if they perceive their own country to be hurt by that trade or if trade talk activates feelings of nationalism.

attributes.title: Transparency and Access to Public Information in Chile, Peru, and Uruguay

q1.value: Transparency and Access to Public Information in Chile, Peru, and Uruguay

q2.value: Rafael Piñeiro | Paula Muñoz-Chirinos | Fernando Rosenblatt | María Cecilia Rossel | Fabrizio Scrollini

q5.value: Fondo Clemente Estable, Agencia Nacional de Investigación e Innovación, Uruguay, project # FCE_1_2017_1_136604. In addition, Fernando Rosenblatt is grateful to the Chilean Millennium Science Initiative–Millennium Institute for Foundational Research on Data for their support and Paula Muñoz is grateful to the Vicerrectorado de Investigación at Universidad del Pacífico.

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q17.value: Process Tracing: H_1: The differences between RTI models in Chile, Uruguay, and Peru are the result of differences in institutional capacities and legacies. The previously existing institutional context affects—either negatively or positively—the processes of approval and implementation of the law. H_2: The differences between RTI models in Chile, Uruguay, and Peru are the result of differences in diffusion processes when initially adopting the laws. H_3: The differences between RTI models in Chile, Uruguay, and Peru result from differences in the coalitions that favor or oppose particular design features and implementation processes. H_4: The differences between RTI models in Chile, Uruguay, and Peru are the result of different contexts of political competition. Field Experiments: Hypothesis 1: Successful use of the FOI law does not increase the level of trust in institutions in general. Hypothesis 2: Successful use of the FOI law increases the level of trust in the specific institution that responds to a given request. Hypothesis 3: Successful use of the FOI law does not increase the perception of transparency in the public sector in general. Hypothesis 4: Successful use of the FOI law increases the perception of transparency in the specific institution that responds to a given request.

registration_responses.q2: Rafael Piñeiro | Paula Muñoz-Chirinos | Fernando Rosenblatt | María Cecilia Rossel | Fabrizio Scrollini
registration_responses.q5: Fondo Clemente Estable, Agencia Nacional de Investigación e Innovación, Uruguay, project # FCE_1_2017_1_136604. In addition, Fernando Rosenblatt is grateful to the Chilean Millennium Science Initiative–Millennium Institute for Foundational Research on Data for their support and Paula Muñoz is grateful to the Vicerrectorado de Investigación at Universidad del Pacífico.

attributes.title: Individually Informed: Personality, news consumption, and affective polarization

q1.value: Individually Informed: Personality, news consumption, and affective polarization

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Recent research has indicated a growing issue of affective polarization in the United States (e.g. Iyengar et al. 2012). Namely, members of the two major parties have grown to be more hostile towards each other. One possible explanation to this phenomenon is the changing media landscape (e.g. Hmielowski et al. 2015; Garrett et al. 2014). As there are more media options to choose from, individuals may get more slanted and biased news. What has not been investigated significantly is the role personality may play in this. Personality, as measured by the big five, has been consistently found to be predictive of political attitudes (e.g. Gerber et al. 2011; Mondak et al. 2010). Relevant to the above discussion are, namely, two major questions: (1) What role does personality play in media selection? And (2) What role does personality play in the effects of media consumption? Kim and Kim (2018) found that openness predicted left-wing news consumption regardless of party. Bachleda et al. (2019) found that conscientiousness predicted increases in negativity bias in news selection (NBNS), while openness, agreeableness and extraversion predicted decreases in NBNS. The relationship between personality and affective polarization was studied by Webster (2018), where he found that extraversion predicted lowered levels of negative partisanship. Conditional on disliking the opposing party, agreeableness predicts lower levels of dislike. To add to the literature, a survey will be launched among Democrats and Republicans, using the survey platform Prolific. Questions about personality, media selection, political attitudes, partisan attitudes, and attitudes towards the media will be asked. Moreover, vignettes will be employed to better assess how personality shapes the interpretations and effects of harsh and sympathetic portrayals of the opposing political party. Some main hypotheses are specified below, however, as this is a newly explored topic, the study will be very exploratory in nature.

q16.value: The main hypotheses can be separated into two parts - hypotheses about media selection and hypotheses about the effects of media consumption. Note: The hypotheses about interactive effects between media consumption (both consumption patterns, and the editorial treatment) and personality are the most speculative hypotheses. To my knowledge these relationships have not been directly studied. Media selection: H1a: Higher levels of openness will predict cross-cutting and more balanced media consumption patterns for both Democrats and Republicans. H1b: Higher levels of openness will predict more left-wing media consumption among both Democrats and Republicans (as compared to people in the same party). H2: Higher levels of conscientiousness will predict more right-wing media consumption among both democrats and Republicans (as compared to people in the same party). Media consumption: H3: Biased media consumption will predict higher levels of affective polarization (i.e. Republicans who consume primarily right-wing content will be more affectively polarized than those who consume more balanced content. Similarly with Democrats and left-wing content.) This effect will be greater among individuals who are (H4) higher in neuroticism, (H5) lower in agreeableness, (H6) and lower in extraversion. H7: Reading an editorial harshly hostile to the opposing side will increase affective polarization. The effect will be stronger in those who are higher in (H8) neuroticism and (H9) conscientiousness, while weaker in those who are higher in (H10) openness, (H11) agreeableness, and (H12) extraversion. H13: Reading an editorial sympathetic to the opposing side will decrease affective polarization. The effect will be stronger in those who are higher in (H14) openness, (H15) agreeableness, and (H16) extraversion. It will be weaker among those higher in (H17) neuroticism, and (H18) conscientiousness.

q17.value: In the first stage of the survey individuals will be given a personality battery (Mini-IPIP Big 5 20-item test), and asked about their political attitudes, including attitudes towards members of the two parties. They will also be given detailed questions about their media consumption habits (what media sources they use and how often). To answer H1 - H6, regression modeling will be used to see if media consumption patterns are predicted by personality, and whether relevant personality traits interact with media consumption to predict affective polarization. In the second stage of the survey most participants will be shown short editorials. Most Democrats will see one of two editorials about Republicans, one will be harshly critical, one sympathetic. Likewise, most Republicans will see one of two editorials about Democrats, one harshly critical, one sympathetic. Some Democrats and Republicans will see no editorial, to serve as control groups. After the editorials, they will be given some questions about what they thought of it, a feeling thermometer about the two parties, and one manipulation check question. The control groups will only get the feeling thermometers. T-tests and regression modeling will be used to assess the impacts of the editorials in general, as well as whether those impacts vary based on personality (H7 - H18). Questions about what they thought of the editorials will be used to help explain the relationships discovered, as well as used for exploratory purposes. Similarly, questions about their overall attitudes towards the media will also be used for similar purposes.

attributes.title: The Impact of Work Risk Factors and Discriminatory Attitudes on Discriminatory Behavior among Swedish Elementary School Principals

q1.value: The Impact of Work Risk Factors and Discriminatory Attitudes on Discriminatory Behavior among Swedish Elementary School Principals

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Why do public officials discriminate? Biased treatment of ethnic minorities still occurs, even in established democracies. The occurrence of such discrimination is disturbing since it may cause serious psychological harm and since treating citizens equal is a vital normative goal of democratic governance. Existing research, mostly undertaken within public administration research is, however, insufficient. Inspired by social psychology insights this project suggest a new approach, focusing on conscious and unconscious discriminatory attitudes. The main hypothesis in our project is that discriminatory behavior is due to such attitudes, in other words not only because officials want to discriminate but because they also unconsciously do so, especially when certain risk factors are present at their work, such as stress or a lack of guidelines. The purpose of our project is therefore to explore how unconscious and conscious discriminatory attitudes affect discriminatory acts among public officials when interacting with individuals belonging to ethnic minorities. We intend to answer the following main research questions: How common is discrimination based on ethnicity, gender and socioeconomic status among Swedish public officials? Are biased acts caused by unconscious attitudes (and not conscious attitudes)? Do certain risk factors at the workplace make discriminatory attitudes more likely to lead to discrimination (e.g., lack of guidelines or lack of minority colleagues)? Are discriminatory attitudes more common under certain workplace conditions?

q16.value: The project focuses on testing the effect of Arabic sounding female/male aliases signaling a low or high socioeconomic status versus Swedish sounding female/male aliases signaling a low or high socioeconomic status on a) the likelihood of replies, and b) the quality of the replies. We will also examine how the discrimination effects vary depending on (1) the work environment of the principals and (2) their discriminatory attitudes and (3) the interaction between the discriminatory attitudes and the work environment. In addition we will analyze how discriminatory attitudes vary depending on the work environment. As this pre-analysis plan covers a large project which will result in a large number of articles, 14 different hypotheses are presented. Each paper will only use a couple of these hypotheses. The dependent variables (e.g. response rate) and the independent variables (e.g. attitudes, risky workplace conditions) used to test the hypotheses are described in more detail in attachments. All the hypotheses are presented in our attached pre-analysis plan.

q17.value: The presence of discrimination will be captured in a field experiment. All Swedish elementary school principals (N= around 3400) will be contacted via emails from fictional aliases. With a correspondence test design, it will be studied whether parents with Arabic-sounding names receive information of the same quality as parents with Swedish-sounding names when it comes to questions these fictitious aliases ask about how the process works when choosing schools. It will also be studied whether women receive information of the same quality as men and whether aliases signaling low socioeconomic status receive information of the same quality as aliases signaling high socioeconomic status. To test our explanatory framework focusing on discriminatory attitudes and workplace environment risk factors, we combine our field experiment data with a unique set of different data sources never before used together within the entire field of discrimination research: tests of unconscious attitudes, registry and survey data. For more information on how we test our hypotheses, see the pre-analysis plan.

attributes.title: Estimating Survey Response Rates for Demographic Questions

q1.value: Estimating Survey Response Rates for Demographic Questions

q2.value: Matthew Baum | Rebecca Goldstein | Maya Sen

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: This study is intended to estimate the survey completion effects of asking U.S. resident survey respondents about their U.S. citizenship status. We would like this study to be informative for the 2020 U.S. Census, which plans to include a citizenship question, and so we would also like to estimate any differential response rate associated with telling survey invitees that their response will be shared with the U.S. Census. Thus, this is a survey experiment with two treatments: a treated survey invitation that either does or does not tell the invitee that their response will be shared with the U.S. Census, and for those who take the survey, a randomly chosen half of respondents will see a citizenship question, and half will not. The rest of the survey will be the other Census questions, as well as some questions about attitudes towards the Census.

q16.value: We have one main hypothesis associated with each of our two experimental treatments. First, we hypothesize that the treatment on the survey invitation (that we will share the respondent’s response with the U.S. Census) will decrease the invitation response rate from 5% to 4%. Second, we hypothesize that the citizenship question treatment will decrease the survey completion rate from 85% to 80%. Additional hypotheses added on 29 October, 2018: 3. We anticipate to see the strongest overall treatment effects on outcomes of interest in the subset of survey respondents who receive both treatment conditions. 4. We anticipate possible heterogeneous treatment effects associated with respondent ideology, regardless of respondent race or ethnicity. Specifically, we hypothesize that a respondent identifying as Democrat/Leaning Democratic is more likely to respond to either or both treatments negatively than are those who identify as Republican/Leans Republican. 5. Among Latina/o respondents, we anticipate possible heterogeneous treatment effects associated with respondent nationality, owing to the fact that two Latina/o groups (Puerto Ricans and Cuban-Americans) tend to be U.S. Citizens. Specifically, we anticipate little or no treatment effect among Puerto Ricans and Cuban Americans, but a negative treatment effect for both treatments among Mexicans and Central Americans (Hondurans, Guatemalans, Salvadorans, etc.). 6. We anticipate that Latina/o and non-whites will respond differently to the attitude questions we posed than non-Latina/o and whites, regardless of treatment status; specifically, Latina/o and non-whites will be less likely than non-Latina/o whites to say that (1) they are likely to participate in the Census, (2) that the Census is important, (3) that the Census will benefit them and they will express more concern (4) that the Census will not keep answers confidential, (5) that the Census will share data with other agencies, and (6) that the Census might be used against them. We also anticipate that Latina/o and non-whites will be more likely than non-Latina/o whites to say that (7) the Census is used to determine whether individuals are in the country legally and that (8) the Census is not supposed to keep data confidential. We anticipate that these differences might be particularly pronounced among those of Mexican and Central American national origin. 7. We anticipate greater expressions of concern over (1) whether census data will be kept private and secure, (2) whether the census data will be used to help a political party, (3) whether it will be used to determine the respondent’s legal status, and (4) whether responses will used to harm the respondent, among respondents receiving either or both treatment conditions, relative to the control condition. We expect treatment effects to be stronger among Latina/o and non-white respondents. 8. We anticipate respondents indicating a lower likelihood of participating in the census if they received either or both treatment conditions, relative to the control conditions. We expect such effects to be stronger among Latina/o and non-white respondents. 9. Because of the ambient political environment (and overall skepticism toward the intentions of the federal government), we anticipate that Latina/o respondents will, regardless of treatment status, be more likely to drop out of the survey and more likely to fail to respond to questions than non-Latina/o whites. We anticipate that these differences might be particularly pronounced among those of Mexican and Central American national origin.

q17.value: These hypotheses will be tested by (1) comparing the survey invitation response rates in the group that does versus does not see an invitation informing them that their response will be shared with the U.S. Census and (2) comparing the survey completion rates in the group that does versus does not see a citizenship question.

q19.value: Approximately 150,000 survey invitees, and approximately 6,000 survey respondents

registration_responses.q1: Estimating Survey Response Rates for Demographic Questions
registration_responses.q2: Matthew Baum | Rebecca Goldstein | Maya Sen
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to any research activities

We would like this study to be informative for the 2020 U.S. Census, which plans to include a citizenship question, and so we would also like to estimate any differential response rate associated with telling survey invitees that their response will be shared with the U.S. Census. Thus, this is a survey experiment with two treatments: a treated survey invitation that either does or does not tell the invitee that their response will be shared with the U.S. Census, and for those who take the survey, a randomly chosen half of respondents will see a citizenship question, and half will not. The rest of the survey will be the other Census questions, as well as some questions about attitudes towards the Census.
registration_responses.q16: We have one main hypothesis associated with each of our two experimental treatments. First, we hypothesize that the treatment on the survey invitation (that we will share the respondent’s response with the U.S. Census) will decrease the invitation response rate from 5% to 4%. Second, we hypothesize that the citizenship question treatment will decrease the survey completion rate from 85% to 80%. Additional hypotheses added on 29 October, 2018: 3. We anticipate to see the strongest overall treatment effects on outcomes of interest in the subset of survey respondents who receive both treatment conditions. 4. We anticipate possible heterogeneous treatment effects associated with respondent ideology, regardless of respondent race or ethnicity. Specifically, we hypothesize that a respondent identifying as Democrat/Leaning Democratic is more likely to respond to either or both treatments negatively than are those who identify as Republican/Leans Republican. 5. Among Latina/o respondents, we anticipate possible heterogeneous treatment effects associated with respondent nationality, owing to the fact that two Latina/o groups (Puerto Ricans and Cuban-Americans) tend to be U.S. Citizens. Specifically, we anticipate little or no treatment effect among Puerto Ricans and Cuban Americans, but a negative treatment effect for both treatments among Mexicans and Central Americans (Hondurans, Guatemalans, Salvadorans, etc.). 6. We anticipate that Latina/o and non-whites will respond differently to the attitude questions we posed than non-Latina/o and whites, regardless of treatment status; specifically, Latina/o and non-whites will be less likely than non-Latina/o whites to say that (1) they are likely to participate in the Census, (2) that the Census is important, (3) that the Census will benefit them and they will express more concern (4) that the Census will not keep answers confidential, (5) that the Census will share data with other agencies, and (6) that the Census might be used against them. We also anticipate that Latina/o and non-whites will be more likely than non-Latina/o whites to say that (7) the Census is used to determine whether individuals are in the country legally and that (8) the Census is not supposed to keep data confidential. We anticipate that these differences might be particularly pronounced among those of Mexican and Central American national origin. 7. We anticipate greater expressions of concern over (1) whether census data will be kept private and secure, (2) whether the census data will be used to help a political party, (3) whether it will be used to determine the respondent’s legal status, and (4) whether responses will used to harm the respondent, among respondents receiving either or both treatment conditions, relative to the control condition. We expect treatment effects to be stronger among Latina/o and non-white respondents. 8. We anticipate respondents indicating a lower likelihood of participating in the census if they received either or both treatment conditions, relative to the control conditions. We expect such effects to be stronger among Latina/o and non-white respondents. 9. Because of the ambient political environment (and overall skepticism toward the intentions of the federal government), we anticipate that Latina/o respondents will, regardless of treatment status, be more likely to drop out of the survey and more likely to fail to respond to questions than non-Latina/o whites. We anticipate that these differences might be particularly pronounced among those of Mexican and Central American national origin.
registration_responses.q17: These hypotheses will be tested by (1) comparing the survey invitation response rates in the group that does versus does not see an invitation informing them that their response will be shared with the U.S. Census and (2) comparing the survey completion rates in the group that does versus does not see a citizenship question.
registration_responses.q19: Approximately 150,000 survey invitees, and approximately 6,000 survey respondents

attributes.title: Electoral Handouts and Partisan Cues as Information in Brazil

q1.value: Electoral Handouts and Partisan Cues as Information in Brazil

q5.value: Department of Political Science, University of Illinois. Lemann Institute for Brazilian Studies, University of Illinois

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Recent researcher have suggested that electoral handouts have an informational purpose, i.e. that giving free gifts to voters in advance of an election signals electoral strength and political competence on the part of the candidate distributing the gift. I suggest that this applies only to cases in which parties are weak (have few resources and no strong brand). When a candidate who comes from a strong party gives handouts, the effect is reversed; voters see the candidate as weak and incompetent, needing to rely on cheap political tactics rather than the advantages offered to them by their party.

q16.value: Hypothesis 1a: For weak parties (those that have few resources and no consistent or clear ideological platform), handouts signal electoral strength and competence. Hypothesis 1b: For strong parties (those that have lots of resources and a credibly coherent ideological brand), handouts signal electoral weakness and incompetence. Hypothesis 2: Candidates who are perceived as electorally strong and competent are more likely to receive support from voters.

q17.value: Survey respondents will read a vignette of a hypothetical candidate. I will randomly vary three aspects of the vignette: whether the candidate gives handouts, the party of the candidate, and the candidate’s incumbency status. Respondents will then answer questions about the candidate, including their likelihood of voting for the candidate and the candidate’s competence and electoral viability.

registration_responses.q1: Electoral Handouts and Partisan Cues as Information in Brazil
registration_responses.q5: Department of Political Science, University of Illinois. Lemann Institute for Brazilian Studies, University of Illinois

I suggest that this applies only to cases in which parties are weak (have few resources and no strong brand). When a candidate who comes from a strong party gives handouts, the effect is reversed; voters see the candidate as weak and incompetent, needing to rely on cheap political tactics rather than the advantages offered to them by their party.

Hypothesis 1b: For strong parties (those that have lots of resources and a credibly coherent ideological brand), handouts signal electoral weakness and incompetence. Respondents will then answer questions about the candidate, including their likelihood of voting for the candidate and the candidate’s competence and electoral viability.

attributes.title: Policing in Multiethnic Societies: A Conjoint Experiment in Uganda

q1.value: Policing in Multiethnic Societies: A Conjoint Experiment in Uganda

q5.value: Thanks to Jennifer Gandhi, David Davis, Danielle Jung for comments on the attached design.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q16.value: 1) civilians are more likely to report to co-ethnic officers (because civilians believe they will be more likely to help) 2) civilians are more likely to report to officers who share the suspect’s ethnicity (because civilians think they will be more effective) 3) civilians are more likely to report to co-ethnic officers if they have past grievances interacting with police 4) civilians are more likely to report to co-ethnic officers if they are engaged in political activities associated with political dissent 5) civilians are more likely to prefer co-ethnic officers if they have experienced past grievances with police.

q17.value: The study employs a survey experiment of respondents in Gulu District, Uganda. In addition to co-ethnic bias, this study examines the effect of other officer char- acteristics (Ranking, Age, Gender); whether the officer pays a reward for information, and the suspect’s social connections to the community. I employ a choice-based conjoint design to explore how ethnicity affects individuals’ willingness to report to police after experiencing a crime.

q24.value: IRB00097514; Research Ethics Committee of Gulu University (GUREC-052-18)

attributes.title: Survey Experimental Study: Moralized Political Messages and Immigration Attitudes in Denmark

q1.value: Survey Experimental Study: Moralized Political Messages and Immigration Attitudes in Denmark

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Much research has sought to understand the bases of opposition to immigration, and two perspectives currently dominate our thinking: economic threat theory and cultural threat theory. However, neither of these perspectives appears to be able to explain the current strength and salience of anti-immigration attitudes, as these attitudes are no longer reserved for the economically disadvantaged and/or strongly conservative segments of society but have moved into the mainstream, even to well-off and liberal groups. In addition, the contemporary polarisation of public opinion is difficult to grasp from a purely economic or cultural threat perspective. I argue that politicians’ moralizing rhetoric on immigration issues is an important missing link in understanding the current opinion climate. This argument builds on the psychological insight that individuals who are morally convicted about an issue tend to hold stronger attitudes (i.e. attitudes that are more extreme and perceived by the individuals that hold them as more psychologically important). Moral conviction is also associated with greater likelihood of dissociating from people who hold opposing views. At the same time, moral conviction is politically mobilising. Taken together these findings suggest that the salience and uncompromising climate characterising contemporary immigration debates may be because many people feel morally convicted about these issues. While some scholars see morality as an intrinsic property of an issue, I argue that politicians play an important role in the process of moralization. To the extent that politicians couch certain topics in a language of right and wrong, moral and immoral, this may affect constituencies to see these topics in a moral light, i.e. to be morally convicted. In turn, this will have consequences for politically relevant attitudes and behaviours, cf. the discussion above. To investigate this claim, I have developed a survey experiment manipulating exposure to moralized political messages on immigration.

q16.value: H1: Exposure to moralized political language increases the level of moral conviction about attitudes to immigration. H2: Moral conviction about immigration is associated with holding more extreme attitudes. H3: Moral conviction about immigration is associated with considering immigration issues as more psychologically important. H4: Moral conviction about immigration is associated with dissociation from opponents. H5a: Exposure to moralized political language only affects convictions and attitudes among respondents who identify with the party sponsor. H5b: Exposure to moralized political language affects convictions and attitudes among party-identifies and non-identifiers in different directions: Both groups will be more morally convicted about immigration but non-identifiers will move in the opposite direction from the political message (i.e. toward more pro-immigration attitudes). Party-identifiers will move in the direction of the message (i.e. toward more anti-immigration attitudes). H5c: Exposure to moralized political language affects respondents equally, with no differences in attitude direction across party-identification. H6: The effects of exposure to moralized political language depends on education, income, and political knowledge/news consumption.

q17.value: In statistical analyses, comparing means on the central outcome variables across respondents exposed to the different treatments + control group, and across subgroups as identified in the hypotheses.

q23.value: the study is registered in the research database of Aarhus University, under AGR-2019-731-8879

registration_responses.q1: Survey Experimental Study: Moralized Political Messages and Immigration Attitudes in Denmark
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to any research activities
registration_responses.q15: Much research has sought to understand the bases of opposition to immigration, and two perspectives currently dominate our thinking: economic threat theory and cultural threat theory. However, neither of these perspectives appears to be able to explain the current strength and salience of anti-immigration attitudes, as these attitudes are no longer reserved for the economically disadvantaged and/or strongly conservative segments of society but have moved into the mainstream, even to well-off and liberal groups. In addition, the contemporary polarisation of public opinion is difficult to grasp from a purely economic or cultural threat perspective. I argue that politicians’ moralizing rhetoric on immigration issues is an important missing link in understanding the current opinion climate. This argument builds on the psychological insight that individuals who are morally convicted about an issue tend to hold stronger attitudes (i.e. attitudes that are more extreme and perceived by the individuals that hold them as more psychologically important). Moral conviction is also associated with greater likelihood of dissociating from people who hold opposing views. At the same time, moral conviction is politically mobilising. Taken together these findings suggest that the salience and uncompromising climate characterising contemporary immigration debates may be because many people feel morally convicted about these issues. While some scholars see morality as an intrinsic property of an issue, I argue that politicians play an important role in the process of moralization. To the extent that politicians couch certain topics in a language of right and wrong, moral and immoral, this may affect constituencies to see these topics in a moral light, i.e. to be morally convicted. In turn, this will have consequences for politically relevant attitudes and behaviours, cf. the discussion above. To investigate this claim, I have developed a survey experiment manipulating exposure to moralized political messages on immigration.

H2: Moral conviction about immigration is associated with holding more extreme attitudes. H3: Moral conviction about immigration is associated with considering immigration issues as more psychologically important. H4: Moral conviction about immigration is associated with dissociation from opponents. H5a: Exposure to moralized political language only affects convictions and attitudes among respondents who identify with the party sponsor. H5b: Exposure to moralized political language affects convictions and attitudes among party-identifies and non-identifiers in different directions: Both groups will be more morally convicted about immigration but non-identifiers will move in the opposite direction from the political message (i.e. toward more pro-immigration attitudes). Party-identifiers will move in the direction of the message (i.e. toward more anti-immigration attitudes). H5c: Exposure to moralized political language affects respondents equally, with no differences in attitude direction across party-identification. H6: The effects of exposure to moralized political language depends on education, income, and political knowledge/news consumption.

attributes.title: Weathering the Storm: Discordant Learning about Reputations for Reliability

q1.value: Weathering the Storm: Discordant Learning about Reputations for Reliability

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: This research focuses on reputations for reliability in alliance behavior. A reputation for reliability is posed as information regarding the likelihood that a state follows through with its alliance commitments. We anticipate that reputation change follows a Bayesian process where reputation acts as a prior while new observation of the state’s behavior act as additional data. The observer then updates the prior using the new data to develop a posterior belief regarding the state’s behavior (an updated reputation). Whether or not there is a change in the quality (good or bad) of a reputation, therefore, depends on the new observations.

q16.value: Good Reputation Hypothesis 1a: When observers are exposed to the moderately incongruent information condition (state only partially complying) they will evaluate a state with a good reputation for reliability consistently. Hypothesis 1b: When observers are exposed to highly incongruent information condition (state not complying) they will evaluate a state with a good reputation for reliability worse than states with middling reputations. Hypothesis 1c: When observers are exposed to congruent information (state fully complying), they will provide a consistent rating of the good reputation state. Middling Reputation Hypothesis 2a: When observers are exposed to the information condition where the state only partially complies, observers will evaluate a state with a middling reputation for reliability worse. Hypothesis 2b: When observers are exposed to the information condition where the state is fully non-compliant, states with a middling reputation will experience a loss in reputation. Hypothesis 2c: : When observers are exposed to the information condition where the state fully complies, the evaluation of the . Bad Reputation Hypothesis 3a: When observers are exposed to the information condition where the state only partially complies, observers will evaluate a state with a bad reputation for reliability consistently. Hypothesis 3b: When observers are exposed to the information condition where the state is fully non-compliant, observers will evaluate a state with a bad reputation for reliability consistently. Hypothesis 3c: When observers are exposed to the information condition where the state is fully compliant, states with a bad reputation will experience an improvement in reputation. Difference between Global and Dyadic Reputations Hypothesis 4: The post-treatment means of global reputations for reliability and dyadic reputation for reliability will be distinct with the mean for global reputation being higher than the mean for dyadic reputation.

q17.value: We will employ a survey experiment using the Mechanical Turk infrastructure.
